questions.text: You are conducting a study to determine the mean height of children visiting the local PHC. Which type of statistical study is being done here?
questions.solution:
A study to determine the mean height of children is an example of a descriptive statistical study.

Descriptive statistics are the statistical methods that merely organize, describe or summarize the actual data available. For example, a study determining the mean blood pressure of patients visiting a PHC on a single day.

Analytical statistics are the second major category of epidemiological studies, after descriptive statistics. The objective of an analytical study is to test the hypothesis.

An observational study is an empiric investigation in which the objective is to establish a relationship between cause and effect. It falls under the category of analytical statistics.

It is performed when controlled experimentation cannot be feasibly used to determine a hypothesis. For example, in the case of cigarette smoking causing lung cancer, it would be unethical and not feasible to conduct a controlled experiment. So, an observational study is preferred.

Inferential statistics involve inductive reasoning i.e., generalizing observations to a population after having observed only a sample. An example of such a study would be a study determining the expected success rate of vasectomy 

Theoretical statistics is a mathematical approach to describe something, predict events, or analyze the relationship between things. Some of the concepts of theoretical statistics are mean, median, mode, standard deviation and correlation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about statistical terms is incorrect?

choices.text: Population is the universe about which an investigator wishes to draw conclusions
A sample is a representative subset of the population that is being studied
An element is a group of observations in the population
A population need not be only people but can be measurements too

questions.solution:
An element is a single observation in a study. For example, in a study of blood pressure values, the blood pressure value of one person is an element.

In a statistical study, the population refers to the group about which information is to be gathered. The composition of the population in terms of its age, sex, occupation, cultural characters, etc need to be defined before a study is conducted. The population need not consist of just people but can also be made of measurements. For example, in a study of blood glucose measurements in Indians, the population consists of the blood glucose measurements.

The part/subset of the population, which is being studied is known as a sample. For example, in a questionnaire-based study on cervical cancer in a population, the sample would include females attending the out-patient departments of a hospital. This is a subset of the entire population.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about probability is true? (Probability of event occurring is p)
  1. p=1 means absolute certainty of event occurring
  2. p can be positive or negative
  3. The addition rule can be used to calculate probability 
  4. The probability of the event not occurring (q ) = p + 1
  5. The multiplication rule can be used to calculate probability
questions.solution:
If the probability of an event occurring is 1, it means there is an absolute certainty that the event will occur.

The addition rule and multiplication rule can be used to calculate the probability of an event. The addition rule is used to calculate the combined probability of the occurrence of two or more mutually exclusive events. The multiplication rule is used to calculate the combined probability of two or more statistically independent events occurring together.

Probability values range from 0 (no probability) to 1 (absolute certainty). So negative value of p is not possible.

Since p is the probability of an event occurring and q is the probability of the event not occurring,

q = 1 - p

Related Pearl: Probability

  • Expressed as a decimal fraction never as a percentage. Denoted by p
  • Must lie between 0 (zero probability) and 1 (absolute certainty).
  • Probability of an event cannot be negative.
  • The probability of an event not occurring (q) is q= 1-p

Rule

Description

Example

The Addition Rule

(p) of any one of several particular events occurring = the sum of their individual probabilities, provided the events cannot both happen and are mutually exclusive.

Probability of picking a heart card from a deck is 0.25 and that of picking a club is 0.25. Thus the p (hearts or clubs) is 0.25 + 0.25 = 0.50.

The Multiplication Rule

(p) of two or more statistically independent events all occurring is = product of their individual probabilities.

If the lifetime probability of a person developing a lung neoplasm is 0.25 and the life time probability of developing dementia is 0.01, then the p (lung neoplasm and dementia) is 0.25 x 0.01 = 0.0025.

The Binomial Distribution

 

(p) of the occurrence of a specific combination of mutually exclusive independent events.

The events for which binomial distribution is used have only two outcomes like yes or no, tall or short, male or female, etc.

 

Widely used in genetic counseling.

questions.text: In which of the following processes is binomial distribution widely used?
questions.solution:
Binomial distribution is widely used in genetic counseling.

Binomial distribution helps determine the probability of occurance of a specific combination of mutually exclusive independent events. In a binomial distribution, there are only two possible events like Yes/No or Male/Female or Alive/Dead. The results of the distribution gives the probabilities of obtaining an exact number of successes in a series of independent trials.

For example, the inheritence of cystic fibrosis follows a binomial distribution. There are:

a. Two possible events - inheriting the disease/ not inheriting it

b. Events are mutually exclusive - one person cannot both have the disease and not have it

c. Independent possibilities - if one child has inherited it, this will not affect if the other child will inherit it.

The physician using this technique can explain to the patients the probabilities of their children suffering from the disease.

questions.text: If the events A and B are mutually exclusive events, what is the probability of either A or B occurring?
questions.solution:
If the events A and B are mutually exclusive, then the probability of either A or B occuring is given by,

p (A or B) = p (A) + p (B)

This is as per the addition rule of probability. 

The probability of both the mutually exclusive events happening at the same time is given by,

p (A and B) = p (A) x p (B)

The probability of any of two mutually non-exclusive events occuring at a point of time is given by,

p (A or B) = p (A) + p (B) - p (A and B)

If p(A) and p(B) are the only two outcomes possible in a given event then,

p (A) + p (B) = 1

For example, probability of patient suffering from lung cancer dying within 5 years and probability of patient suffering from lung cancer surviving these 5 years adds upto 1.

questions.text: You are conducting a study on birth weight. As per your data, the probability of a baby having birth weight <2500 grams is 0.50 and of having birth weight of 2500-2999 grams is 0.20. What is the probability that a baby will have a birth weight of < 3kg?
questions.solution:
The probability that a baby will have a birth weight of < 3kg is 0.70.

In this scenario, the probability of having a baby with BW < 2500 grams, p (A) = 0.50 and that of having a baby with BW between 2500 – 2999 grams, p (B) = 0.20.

Since both events are mutually exclusive, i.e., they cannot happen together, it satisfies the condition for the addition rule of probability.

Thus, the probability of having a baby that weighs less than 3 kilos is,

p (A or B) = p (A) + p (B) = 0.50 + 0.20 = 0.70.

If p(A) and p(B) were non-mutually exclusive events, then the probability would have been calculated by

p(A or B) = p(A) + p(B) - p(A and B).

questions.text: You select 3  people from a population where the prevalence of anemia is 20% .What is the probability that all the three randomly selected people from the population would have anemia?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the probability of all 3 randomly selected individuals having anemia is 0.008.

In this scenario, the prevalence of anemia is 20%.

So, the probability of a person having anemia in the given population (p) = 20/100 = 0.2.

If selecting 3 people from the population randomly, the chance of the first person having anemia is independent of the second or third person also having it and vice versa. This satisfies the condition for the multiplication rule of probability which states that the probability of two or more statistically independent events all occurring together is equal to the product of their individual probabilities. 

Thus, here the probability that all the 3 randomly selected people from the population would have anemia = 0.2 x 0.2 x 0.2 = 0.008.

questions.text: There are 50 patients admitted in a ward of your medical college. Here 20 are girls and 30 are boys. Out of this, 10 girls and 20 boys require surgery. What is the probability that a randomly selected boy and girl both require surgery?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the probability that a randomly selected boy and girl both require surgery is 1/3.

First, we have to calculate the probability of picking the boys requiring surgery and the girls requiring surgery separately. These are mutually exclusive events.

In this scenario, the probability of correctly picking a girl requiring surgery is p(A)=10/20= 1/2

The probability of correctly picking a boy requiring surgery is p(B)=20/30= 2/3

Next, we apply the multiplication rule of probability.

The probability of picking boys and girls that require surgery,

p(A and B)= p(A) x p(B)= ½ x ⅔ = 2/6= 1/3.

questions.text: The chance of passing a genetic disease X by affected parents to their first child is 0.16. If they plan to have two children, what is the probability that both the children will have the disease?
questions.solution:
The probability of both children having the disease is 0.0256.

In this scenario, the chance of each child having the disease is 0.16. The second child having the disease is independent of the first child having it. So, the events are statistically independent.

Applying the multiplication rule of probability, the probability of both children having the disease is,

0.16 x 0.16 = 0.0256.
These are non-mutually exclusive events as the first child having the trait does not rule out the chance of the second child having it.   

On the other hand, the probability of one of the two children having the disease is given by,

p(A or B)= p(A) + p(B) - p(A and B)= 0.16 + 0.16 -(0.16 x 0.16)= 0.32- 0.0256= 0.2944

questions.text: Which of the following is not a measurement scale for data?
questions.solution:
A proportion is not a measurement scale for data. It is a ratio, where the numerator is always a part of the denominator. It indicates a value as a part of the whole. It is usually expressed as a percentage.

The four scales of measurement used for data can be remembered with the mnemonic NOIR. This stands for nominal, ordinal, interval and ratio data scales.

Related Pearl: Scales of data measurement

Data can be quantitative (numerical values) or qualitative (types, labels).

Quantitative data can be discrete variables or continuous variables.

 

Description

Example

Discrete data

Can take certain values and none in between

Number of cancer patients in a hospital. 

Continuous data

Can take any value usually in between limits or a range. 

Most biomedical data is continuous.

Height, weight, blood pressure, etc.

 

Data always forms one of four scales of measurement – nominal, ordinal, interval, or ratio scales (mnemonic: NOIR):

 

Nominal Scale Data

Ordinal Scale Data

Interval Scale Data

Ratio Scale Data

Example

Male/female; red/green; sub-urban/rural

Students ranked 1st/2nd/3rd in their class. 

A customer feedback survey using terms like very good, good, poor and very poor or the Likert Scale.

Severity of a disease as mild, moderate, severe

 

 Measurements on the celsius scale. Pulse rate; 

Notes

Have no quantitative value.

They have no order or ratio. 

Arranged in a meaningful order.

No size interval is defined

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Example: Temperature in Celsius. If temperature in A is 40 deg Celsius and that in B is 20 deg Celsius, then A is 20 deg Celsius hotter than B (taking difference)

Does not have an absolute zero.

For example, Celsius scale has no such thing as “no temperature”. So the value cannot be zero.

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Eg: A pulse rate has well defined intervals and is meaningful in comparison. A 100/min pulse is exactly twice of 50 beats/min.

 

Has an absolute zero.

Eg: There can be a value of zero for pulse.

Type

Qualitative

Qualitative

Quantitative

Quantitative

questions.text:
Which of the following are examples of nominal scale data?
  1. Genders
  2. Types of hospitals
  3. Height
  4. Kuppuswamy scale
  5. Types of anemia
questions.solution:
Genders, types of anemia and types of hospitals come under nominal scale data.

There is no meaningful order or quantifiable variable in this kind of data. It is arranged on the basis of labels, titles or categories.

Kuppuswamy scale is an ordinal scale data. It is a scale representing socio-economic data.

Height is a ratio scale data as it can be arranged in a meaningful order with a well-defined size interval.

questions.solution:
The classification of this disease as normal, mild, moderate and severe belongs to the ordinal scale. This is because this arrangement is not only qualitative but also has a meaningful order with no interval in between.

questions.text:
Which of the following are representative of ordinal scale data?
  1. Hemoglobin level
  2. TNM staging
  3. Likert scale
  4. HIV positive or negative 
  5. Severity of pain
questions.solution:
TNM staging, Likert scale and severity of pain are measured on the ordinal scale.

In such cases, the arrangement is qualitative, with a meaningful order but there is no way of quantifying the difference between the individual variables. For example, grading of pain as mild, moderate, and severe.

The Likert scale is used in collecting self-reported data in questionnaire-based research. It is a psychometric scale used to understand people’s attitudes from responses. Usually, a 5-point scale of agreement is used which includes:

  • 1 – Strongly disagree
  • 2 – Disagree
  • 3 – Neither agree nor disagree
  • 4 – Agree
  • 5 – Strongly agree

TNM staging is done for the staging of cancer. It is based on tumor size, lymph node status and metastasis. Lower stages indicate better prognosis than higher stages.

Hemoglobin level is an example of ratio scale data.

HIV positive or negative status falls under the category of nominal scale data.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a continuous variable?

choices.text: Blood glucose value of a diabetic patient
Number of visits to the hospital in a year

questions.solution:
The number of visits to the hospital in a year is a discrete variable. The only values it can take are whole numbers and none in between. For example, you can’t visit the hospital 2.5 times.

Blood glucose value, mid-arm circumference and birth weight are continuous variables. They can have any value within a limit or a range.

questions.text:
Match the following.
Data Scale of data
1) Number of cancer patients in a hospital  a) Discrete data
2) Height and weight b) Interval scale data
3) Blood pressure measurements c) Ratio scale data
4) Temperature measurement in Celsius  
5) Temperature measurement in Kelvin
questions.solution:
The number of cancer patients in a hospital is an example of discrete data. They can only take certain values and none in between.

The temperature measured in the Celsius scale is an example of interval scale data. Such data are arranged in a meaningful order but they can not have an absolute zero value. For example, 80 degree celcius to not twice as hot as 40 degree celcius and 0 degree celcius does not indicate an absolute abscence of heat.

Height and weight, blood pressure and temperature in the Kelvin scale are examples of ratio scale data. Such data are arranged in a meaningful order and the scales they are measured in have absolute zero value. For example, a temperature of 0 kelvin indicates an absolute abscense of heat.

Height and weight, blood pressure, and temperature are examples of continuous data as they can take any values between limits or a range.

Related Pearl: Scales of data measurement

Data can be quantitative (numerical values) or qualitative (types, labels).

Quantitative data can be discrete variables or continuous variables.

 

Description

Example

Discrete data

Can take certain values and none in between

Number of cancer patients in a hospital. 

Continuous data

Can take any value usually in between limits or a range. 

Most biomedical data is continuous.

Height, weight, blood pressure, etc.

 

Data always forms one of four scales of measurement – nominal, ordinal, interval, or ratio scales (mnemonic: NOIR):

 

Nominal Scale Data

Ordinal Scale Data

Interval Scale Data

Ratio Scale Data

Example

Male/female; red/green; sub-urban/rural

Students ranked 1st/2nd/3rd in their class. 

A customer feedback survey using terms like very good, good, poor and very poor or the Likert Scale.

Severity of a disease as mild, moderate, severe

 

 Measurements on the celsius scale. Pulse rate; 

Notes

Have no quantitative value.

They have no order or ratio. 

Arranged in a meaningful order.

No size interval is defined

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

questions.text: Identify the following representation of data.
questions.solution:
The image shown is of a boxplot. This is a method for graphically depicting groups of numerical data through their quartiles.

Box plots may also have lines extending vertically from the boxes (i.e., whiskers) indicating variability outside the upper and lower quartiles. Hence, they are also known as box-and-whisker plots and box-and-whisker diagrams.

The below image shows a boxplot depicting a series of experiments done to calculate the velocity of light.

A stem and leaf plot is used to depict frequency distribution and individual values for numerical data. The stem is are usually arranged in ascending or descending order vertically, and a vertical line is drawn to separate it from the leaf. The number of leaf items total up to the number of observations. It is difficult to represent a large number of observations using this method.

The below image shows a stem and leaf plot.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: The following diagram charts the population change over years from 1983 to 1989 in a given place. What is the statistical diagram used here?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a component bar graph. It is used to represent data in which the total magnitude is divided into different subsets or components.

A bar chart or bar graph is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data. They can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

The image given below shows a multiple bar graph showing the human losses of world war II by country. In a multiple bar chart, 2 or more sets of data are shown simultaneously.  

A bar chart can be distinguished from a histogram because the rectangles are separated by the spaces. This indicates that the data forms discrete categories.

In a histogram, the rectangles are not separated by spaces as the data represented forms a continuous set instead of discrete groups.

questions.text: During a cholera outbreak, you are asked to map the geographical distribution of the disease. What is the best method of doing this?
questions.solution:
Dot-density maps are the best way to plot the geographical distribution of diseases.

The image given below shows a dot-density map of London that was plotted during the 1854 outbreak of cholera.

A dot-density map was used by Dr John Snow when a large outbreak of cholera occurred in London in 1854. Initially, it was believed that bad smells/ air from rotting organic matter spread the disease. He demonstrated the link between contaminated drinking water and cholera. He mapped the disease and identified the source to be a contaminated public water pump in Broad street, London.
